bboxes.raw_text:
PHILADELPHIA = Six gradu-
ates of southern colleges who will
receive degrees in home eco
nomics, were guests of Scott
Paper Company for a three day
visit to Philadelphia.


The six had received two year
scholarships from the paper
company. They are Misses Cora
E. Bowie. Howard University:
Doris Kennedy, Maryland State
College: Shirley M. Lovett. Tus-
kegee Institute: Vernice B. Guy.
Hampton Institute: Ernestine
Holiday. Clark College; and Bet
tye Boone, Virginia State College.


The students toured Scott
Paper Plant at Chester: Phila-
delphia Electric Co.: Farm Jour-
nal Magazine test kitchens.
Mercy Douglass Hospital. Bonwit
Teller Store and City Hall.


They we're received at cityhal
by Commissioner Of Records
Clarence DICKENS and Judge Ray
mond P. Alexander.

Evin Allen Knight. son of Pvt.
and Mrs. Nathaniel Knight, born
March l6. 1864. died May Is.


He is survived by his mater
nal grandmother, Mrs. Legusta
Moss and paternal grandparents.
Mr.. and Mrs. E. A. Knight, of
Phoenix.


Interment was at Greenwood
Cemetery.

May nth marked the first decade Of school
integYation brought about by the United States
SUPREME Courts historic ruling. This 2uI1ng
stated that schools could be no longer admin
isteYed as separate schools for only Negroes.


The Supreme Court de cisiOn WuS to be toI-
loVed with deliberate speed. In many areas
the speed has been almost a smails pace. In
some areas where q fen all Negro schools
sOeYe permanently closed, indignation came
more swiftly.


School desegyegatiOn or school segyega-
tion in other areas outside Of the Deep South
are caused by school boundaries and housing
areas. De tacto segregation wiu continue as
long as housing patterns remain the same.


Movements in urban areas to change the
school boundaries has caused more legal
battles and the np0ving Of children by busseS
to areas far from their homes mil cause
bitter scenes.


Within the next ten years there aOiH be a
greater per cent Of Negro pupils attending
schools with Caucasian ones. The next ten
years should see similar changes in housing
patterns, too.


De tacto segregation is caused by number
of things and aOkile 1T would be unre0hStic TO
saw complete school Indignation Mould EXIST
de tacto segregation is caused by more things
than dYaaOiNgS on a map.


Let us work TOWARD not only greater school
imtegyation, but TOWARD greater use Of school
OPPORTUNITIES which are already open to us.

DRIVER WANTED


FREE Observation-Disclosures
drive to Oklahoma. Leave the
first week in June APP $500
